ArticleTitle.sentence: Characterization of a mutant cell line that does not activate NF-kappaB in response to multiple stimuli.

event.clue: Characterization of a mutant cell line that does not activate NF-kappaB in response to multiple stimuli.

AbstractText.sentence: Numerous genes required during the immune or inflammation response as well as the adhesion process are regulated by nuclear factor kappaB (NF-kappaB).

event.clue: Numerous genes required during the immune or inflammation response as well as the adhesion process are regulated by nuclear factor kappaB (NF-kappaB).

AbstractText.sentence: Associated with its inhibitor, I kappaB, NF-kappaB resides as an inactive form in the cytoplasm.

event.clue: Associated with its inhibitor, I kappaB, NF-kappaB resides as an inactive form in the cytoplasm.

AbstractText.sentence: Upon stimulation by various agents, I kappaB is proteolyzed and NF-kappaB translocates to the nucleus, where it activates its target genes.

AbstractText.sentence: The transduction pathways that lead to I kappaB inactivation remain poorly understood.

AbstractText.sentence: In this study, we have characterized a cellular mutant, the 70/Z3-derived 1.3E2 murine pre-B cell line, that does not activate NF-kappaB in response to several stimuli.

event.clue: In this study, we have characterized a cellular mutant, the 70/Z3-derived 1.3E2 murine pre-B cell line, that does not activate NF-kappaB in response to several stimuli.

AbstractText.sentence: We demonstrate that upon stimulation by lipopolysaccharide, Taxol, phorbol myristate acetate, interleukin-1, or double-stranded RNA, I kappaB alpha is not degraded, as a result of an absence of induced phosphorylation on serines 32 and 36.

AbstractText.sentence: Neither a mutation in I kappaB alpha nor a mutation in p50 or relA, the two major subunits of NF-kappaB in this cell line, accounts for this phosphorylation defect.

AbstractText.sentence: As well as culminating in the inducible phosphorylation of I kappaB alpha on serines 32 and 36, all the stimuli that are inactive on 1.3E2 cells exhibit a sensitivity to the antioxidant pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate (PDTC).

AbstractText.sentence: Analysis of the redox status of 1.3E2 does not reveal any difference from wild-type 70Z/3.

AbstractText.sentence: Our results demonstrate that 1.3E2 is a cellular transduction mutant exhibiting a defect in a step that is required by several different stimuli to activate NF-kappaB.
